title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, 1 june [1870]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 1 June [1870]
text: 1870June 1 My dear Walteri did feel so ansiousanxious to hear from you and i cantcan't help but feel quite down hearted to hear your thumb is so bad yet i am so sorry for you to have such a tedious long time but i hope you will have it all come right in time but it seemesseems a long time it seemesseems sometimes as if a sore never will get well and then at other times it will heal very quick it is too bad) how doodo you do to write at the office or dontdon't you i wish you could write what the doctor thinks of it and what you put on it but i dontdon't want to have you write any extras because i know by the writing it must be difficult for you i long for a letter so bad thinking you will be better the next one but i hope you will not get discouraged my dear walterWalter for it certainly will get well) i had a letter from Jeff he said they had the radical and was much pleased with the peecepiece in it we had a greadgreat day here on mondayMonday as likewise you had in washingtonWashington decorating the soldierssoldier's graves) i suppose walterWalter you saw the death of richardRichard huntHunt in the papers he was buried on mondayMonday at 2 oclocko'clock at his residence at stantonStanton st i saw it was about 11 in the forenoon and i thought i must go i went up to mytle avMyrtle Ave. and got me a pair of gloves and when i got back i was so lame i had to give it up as i would have to walk several bloksblocks i was afraid to undertake it what ailed him i dontdon't know i belivebelieve his children are all married) i expect georgeGeorge home on saturdaySaturdaygood bie walterWalter dear dontdon't get discoureddiscouragedthe order has come with many obligations Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 1 June [1870]
